title: What are some fun creative writing prompts for beginners? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Fun” is in the eye of the beholder. I can’t tell you what might be fun for you; only you can do that. That said, there are some simple things you can try, and see if they work for you: Go to a public place (shopping mall, park, sports event, etc.) and watch people. Listen to how they talk. Notice what they’re saying—some of it will be pretty mundane because you’re lacking context, but some will likely catch your ear, and make you wonder…what were they talking about? What happened next? Voila—a ready-made writing prompt. If listening isn’t your thing so much, watch how people interact. notice their clothing. What does it say about them? Pick someone who looks ordinary and build a backstory for them. Pick someone who looks anything but ordinary and do the same.Pull a book off your shelf. Open it to a random page. Take the first sentence you see and use it to start a story.Pull a book off your shelf, open to a random page, take the first five words you see and work them (not necessarily in order) into a story.Use the first line of a famous novel to begin a completely different story.Ask five people for one random word each, and use them to develop a story.There are also books of prompts, and apps with prompts. I haven’t suggested any because inspiration is really all around you all the time. You just have to learn to pay attention, and you’ll start seeing it everywhere. The suggestions I’ve given you will help you do just that. There’s nothing wrong with using apps or books, but I think it’s better to use the real world as a prompt-on-demand than to become dependent on outside sources. Good luck!

Ask someone to gather up a dozen things and place them together on one table. Think about each item and how you might link it to another item. Start writing down whatever thoughts come to you. Then go and do other things. Each time you return to the table look for connections again.Send a message to 10 friends asking them each to send you a list of 5 nouns and 5 verbs. Transfer all words to a single Word page. Do any of the words 100 words pop out at you? Do you see something you’d like to write about? If not, try connecting as many of the words are possible into full sentences. This exercise sometimes greases the wheel for me. Don’t feel like you have to use every word.Describe a room from your childhood.Tell about the most memorable morning you can remember.Write a letter to you 93 year-old self.Write a letter to your 9 year-old self.Begin a poem with, “This was before …”Begin a poem with, “It began as a soft whisper.”Begin a poem with, “Sit here with me and tell…”Go to 101 Poetry Writing Prompts
